title: Custom Chat Agent Mode Reset on Edit
body:
**Version:** `1.103.0-insider (Universal)`
**Commit:** `05ca6dd1bd6690aa2be81cc940ec308e5acc1c3d`
**Date:** `2025-08-05T15:44:58.613Z`
**Electron:** `37.2.3`
**ElectronBuildId:** `12035395`
**Chromium:** `138.0.7204.100`
**Node.js:** `22.17.0`
**V8:** `13.8.500258-electron.0`
**OS:** `Darwin arm64 25.0.0`

---

### 🧪 Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create and select a **custom chat mode agent** (e.g., `example-agent`).
2. Send a message in the chat using the selected custom agent.
3. Click the sent message to ✎ **edit**.
4. Observe that the edit box's **mode dropdown resets** to one of the **default modes** (e.g., `Ask`, `Edit`, or `Agent`) instead of preserving the selected custom agent.
5. Without making any edits, **close the edit box**.
6. Observe that the **mode dropdown for the new message also resets**.

---

### ❌ Observed Behavior:

* ✅ **Bug 1:** The **edit box resets to a built-in chat mode**, not the one the original message was sent with. If the edit is submitted, it is incorrectly sent using this **new (and wrong) agent**.
* ✅ **Bug 2:** After **canceling the edit**, the **new message dropdown remains incorrectly changed**, and any **new message is sent using the wrong agent** (a built-in one instead of the previously selected custom agent).

---

### ✅ Expected Behavior:

* The **agent selected during original message send** should be preserved during edit and shown in the edit dropdown.
* Canceling the edit should **not alter the current chat mode agent selection**.
* Subsequent messages should continue using the previously selected **custom agent** unless manually changed.

title: Show Built-in Tools at the bottom, collapsed or in a seperate tab

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
When you go to the list of MCP Tools, the Built in tools take up all of the initial screen (don't know if this is designed that way or the fact it start with "B"

In any case, 99% of the time when you go to this list it is not to interact with the Built-in tools, but to see/enable/disable/debug a custom tool, so that result in that you need to scroll down every single time.

I suggest that you do one of 3 things:

1. You add 2 Tabs at the top of the list called "Built-in" and "Custom" (And start on "Custom" if there are any)
2. You always display the Built-in tools at the bottom
3. You always start all tool in a collapsed state only showing the MCP Server Name

title: Unable to use 'Manage Models...' for organization accounts despite model permissions enabled
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version:
Version: 0.29.1

- VS Code Version:
版本: 1.102.3 (user setup)
提交: 488a1f239235055e34e673291fb8d8c810886f81
日期: 2025-07-29T03:00:23.339Z
Electron: 35.6.0
ElectronBuildId: 11847422
Chromium: 134.0.6998.205
Node.js: 22.15.1
V8: 13.4.114.21-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100

- OS Version:
Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.26100.4652]


**Issue Summary**
For accounts under an organization, the "Manage Models..." option in Copilot Chat is inaccessible. However, in the organization settings (Settings > Models > Development), permission to use models has already been enabled.

**Steps to Reproduce**
1. Log in with an account under an organization.
2. Confirm that in Organization Settings > Models > Development, model usage is allowed (All publishers).
3. Open Copilot Chat in VS Code and attempt to access "Manage Models...".

**Expected Behavior**
The "Manage Models..." menu should be available if organization permissions allow model usage.

**Actual Behavior**
The menu remains unavailable/disabled for organization accounts.

**Additional Context**
- Organization settings confirm model usage is permitted.
- When I reopen VSCode, the 'Manage Models...' feature is still missing.

**Request**
- Guidance on resolving this issue or clarification if this is an intentional limitation.
- Suggestions for troubleshooting or escalation if this is a bug.

Thank you for your assistance.

title: MCP: VS Code floods GitHub MCP with JSON-RPC `ping`s, trips API rate limit (HTTP 429)
body:
VS Code's mcp endpoint checks cause too many requests on GitHub's MCP server.

Ending in:

```
2025-08-05 19:40:58.024 [trace] Fetched https://api.githubcopilot.com/mcp/: {"status":429,"headers":{"content-length":"18","content-security-policy":"default-src 'none'; sandbox","content-type":"text/plain; charset=utf-8","date":"Wed, 06 Aug 2025 02:40:57 GMT","retry-after":"3","strict-transport-security":"max-age=31536000","x-content-type-options":"nosniff","x-github-backend":"Kubernetes","x-github-request-id":"F40D:2DB396:D9D10D:117ABDF:6892C0B9"}}
2025-08-05 19:40:58.034 [info] Connection state: Error 429 status sending message to https://api.githubcopilot.com/mcp/: too many requests
```

Logs narrated by o3:

> **What happened**
> 
> * The **server** sent a burst of JSON-RPC `ping` requests to the **editor** with IDs **27 → 134** (≈108 pings).
> * Each `ping` received an immediate `result:{}` from the editor.
> * For each completed RPC, the client POSTed to `https://api.githubcopilot.com/mcp/`.
> * The MCP endpoint returned many **202 Accepted** responses, then switched to **429 Too Many Requests** with `Retry-After: 3`.
> * The client reported: **“Connection state: Error 429 … too many requests.”**
> 
> **Timing (from log)**
> 
> * First burst: `19:40:57.039` (IDs 27–60).
> * Second burst: `19:40:57.250–19:40:57.258` (IDs 61–128).
> * Final mini-burst: `19:40:57.450–19:40:57.452` (IDs 129–134).
> * Rate-limit error observed at `19:40:58.024` with `Retry-After: 3`.
> 
> **Expected**
> 
> * Keep-alive/health checks (`ping`) are throttled; downstream MCP calls stay within server limits; no 429s.
> 
> **Observed**
> 
> * \~108 `ping` RPCs and corresponding POSTs within \~0.4s caused an HTTP 429 and connection error.
> 
> **Impact**
> 
> * MCP connection enters an error state; follow-on requests may fail until manual retry/backoff.
> 
> **Notes / hypotheses**
> 
> * Likely missing/thin throttling on `ping` dispatch or response forwarding.
> * The client did not appear to honor `Retry-After: 3` before logging an error.
> 
> **Suggestions**
> 
> * Debounce/limit `ping` frequency; avoid per-ping POSTs or batch them.
> * Implement client-side rate limiting with exponential backoff and respect `Retry-After`.
> * Consider switching to a periodic heartbeat (single inflight) instead of parallel `ping`s.
> 
> **Log snippets**
> 
> ```
> [server -> editor] {"id":27,"method":"ping"} … {"id":134,"method":"ping"}
> …
> Fetched https://api.githubcopilot.com/mcp/: {"status":202}
> …
> Fetched https://api.githubcopilot.com/mcp/: {"status":429,"headers":{"retry-after":"3"}}
> [info] Connection state: Error 429 … too many requests
> ```

title: 💄 Todo list widget: Muted design and progress scrolling
body:
## Summary

Enhances the chat todo list widget with comprehensive UX improvements including progress indicators, smart scrolling, and refined styling.

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c10b7dcc-8baa-4625-9bfa-8263566c3cc4


## Changes

### Core Features
- **Progress Indicator**: Changes "Tasks" → "Todos" with dynamic progress display (e.g., "Todos (2/5)")
- **Smart Scrolling**: Auto-scrolls to relevant items with workflow-aware positioning
- **Refined Styling**: Less prominent header with compact, muted appearance

### Technical Improvements
- **TypeScript**: Added `getProgressText()` method and `scrollToRelevantItem()` with intelligent positioning logic
- **CSS**: Responsive sizing using `calc(6.5 * 24px)`, scroll snap behavior, and modern scrollbar styling
- **UX**: Shows 6.5 items with half-line affordance, prioritizes in-progress items, handles edge cases

### Behavior
- **Empty state**: Shows "Todos" 
- **With progress**: Shows "Todos (X/Y)" format
- **Scrolling**: Centers active items, shows completed context, scrolls to top when all items are not-started
- **Responsive**: Uses VS Code's standard calc() patterns for maintainable sizing

## Testing
- ✅ TypeScript compilation successful
- ✅ Follows VS Code localization patterns
- ✅ Maintains existing widget functionality
- ✅ CSS follows VS Code design system

title: [GHCP] Easier Multiple Named Chat Tabs | Easier Multiple Active Simultaneous Concurrent Conversations Chat Tabs

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body: ## Feature Request: Support for Multiple Simultaneous Chat Sessions in GitHub Copilot for VS Code It would be extremely useful to support **multiple named chat conversations for specialized roles** in GitHub Copilot in the side chat panel, allowing users to work sequentially but in **parallel chat histories** - just like in-editor multiple chats work. This would provide a large comfort and clarity increase, while avoiding many coordination issues and complexities of true concurrency (as proposed in [#242318](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/242318) ). #### Why this matters: When working with CLI-based agents like Gemini or Claude, I typically maintain **4+ active chat tabs**, each named, launched with a shortcut command, dedicated to a specific role or task—e.g., architect, developer (backend, frontend, ops), or QA. While they share access to documentation, each agent focuses only on its domain, dramatically improving task efficiency and reducing off-topic drift, as well as reducing to almost none the risk of editing the same files at the same time. This approach mirrors how a real team works—clear ownership, focused context, and reduced cognitive load. #### Example Workflow: 1. A new feature is requested. 2. **Architect agent** researches online, gathers documentation, and creates a high-level design and `tasks.md` . 3. **Developer agent** reads the docs, picks a task, and creates a new `task.md` with a step-by-step plan. 4. Developer progresses through `task.md` steps, tracking progress in the same task file. 5. Once complete, the **QA agent** reads the `task.md` and docs, tests the implementation, and prepares a `task-qa-report.md` 6. If issues are found: * For implementation bugs, the developer reviews the `task-qa-report.md`and fixes the issue. * For design flaws, the architect revisits the docs and `task-qa-report.md` and updates the design as needed, and adds relevant task to the `tasks.md` and to the `task.md` with necessary changes 7. This loop continues until QA passes. 8. Architect marks the top-level task as complete. 9. Developer moves on to the next task and creates another task-specific `task.md` This modular, chat-tabbed approach is **vastly more effective** than maintaining a single monolithic conversation. It also improves **token efficiency** by scoping prompts and context to just the relevant agent, instead of loading the entire project history each time. Having tabs directly in the side panel would make navigating and previewing the work much easier. #### Suggested Implementation: * Add support for **multiple chat tabs** within Copilot Chat side panel in VS Code. * Each tab should maintain its own context, configuration, and history - just like having multiple conversations in editor work. * Users can name tabs (e.g., “Architect,” “Backend Dev,” “QA”) to reflect their role or function - this could also be added to the multi conversation in editor. * Simplify saving roles and prompts for the roles or creating these specialized agents * Add an UI indication which tabs have made edits last or have pending edits to keep * This complements, rather than replaces, concurrent development workflows (e.g., using worktrees with multiple instances of VS Code running then resolving merge conflicts with an agent, or in the future handling this directly within the UI as proposed in [#242318](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/242318) ) #### Impact: This feature would significantly increase comfort of using multiple conversations and make GitHub Copilot more suitable for **complex, full-stack projects** involving multi-agent workflows, while still allowing good preview of the edits. Personally, this would be a strong enough reason to switch back from CLI-based agents to Copilot within VS Code. With this approach it would still be down to the user to ensure the agents don't edit the same files in parallel, and the current handling of file edits would suffice. GH could provide some preconfigured roles for an easier startup, I'm happy to share my prompts for that. #### Known Workaround: Move the conversations to in-editor chats or in the new window. The issue with this is that it gets really cluttered and obscures the editor view.

title: Fix DEBUG CONSOLE not detecting file paths with ANSI escape sequences
body:
The DEBUG CONSOLE was not recognizing file paths containing ANSI escape sequences as clickable links. When debugging applications that output colored text with ANSI codes, file paths would not be properly detected, making navigation to source files difficult.

Consider this debug output:

```javascript
console.log("/tmp/abc.js\x1b[0m:1:7");
```

The DEBUG CONSOLE would fail to detect the complete path `/tmp/abc.js:1:7` as clickable because the ANSI escape sequence `\x1b[0m` interfered with the pattern matching in the link detector.

## Root Cause

The issue was in the `handleANSIOutput` function in `debugANSIHandling.ts`. When processing text with ANSI sequences, the function would flush text buffers at ANSI sequence boundaries, causing `appendStylizedStringToContainer` to be called with truncated text fragments like `/tmp/abc.js` and `:1:7` separately, preventing the link detector from seeing the complete file path.

## Solution

The fix modifies `handleANSIOutput` to:

1. **Use `forAnsiStringParts` for reliable ANSI parsing** - Replaces manual character-by-character parsing with the robust `forAnsiStringParts` function
2. **Pre-detect links in cleaned text** - Checks if the text without ANSI codes contains links before processing
3. **Handle single-link scenarios specially** - When one link spans the entire content, preserves ANSI codes in the final link element for colored display
4. **Fall back gracefully** - Uses original processing for complex cases with multiple links

## Testing

Added comprehensive test cases covering:
- Basic ANSI at end of path: `/tmp/abc.js\x1b[0m:1:7`
- ANSI codes in middle of path: `/tmp/a\x1b[31mbc.js\x1b[0m:1:7`
- Ensures no regression for normal paths without ANSI codes

The fix ensures that file paths with ANSI escape sequences are now properly detected as clickable links, including line and column information, while preserving the colored output display in the DEBUG CONSOLE.

Fixes #250942.

title: Fix debug console collapsing identical lines to work on text lines instead of events
body:
The debug console's logic for collapsing identical lines was operating on individual output events from debug adapters rather than actual text lines. This caused two main issues:

## Problems Fixed

**1. Character-by-character output incorrectly collapsed**
When debug adapters send output character-by-character (common with unbuffered I/O on embedded devices), VS Code would collapse identical characters instead of forming complete lines first:

```typescript
// Debug adapter sends these events:
this.sendEvent(new OutputEvent("5"));
this.sendEvent(new OutputEvent("5"));
this.sendEvent(new OutputEvent("\n"));

// OLD: Shows "(2)5" instead of "55"
// NEW: Correctly shows "55"
```

**2. Single events with multiple identical lines not collapsed**
When a debug adapter sends multiple identical lines in a single event, they weren't being collapsed:

```typescript
// Debug adapter sends:
this.sendEvent(new OutputEvent("it\nit\n"));

// OLD: Shows two separate "it" lines
// NEW: Correctly shows "(2)it"
```

## Solution

The fix modifies `ReplModel.appendToRepl()` to work with actual text lines rather than raw events:

- **Line-based processing**: Multi-line output is parsed into individual lines before applying collapsing logic
- **Character aggregation**: Character-by-character output is concatenated into complete lines before considering collapsing
- **Backward compatibility**: Preserves existing behavior for line concatenation and respects severity/source differences
- **Complex scenarios**: Handles mixed single-event and multi-line scenarios correctly

## Technical Changes

- Added `appendOutputToRepl()`, `processMultiLineOutput()`, `splitIntoLines()`, `applyLineLevelCollapsing()`, and `tryCollapseCompleteLine()` methods
- Modified the main `appendToRepl()` method to delegate to line-based logic
- Enhanced collapsing detection to work when character-by-character output forms complete identical lines

The fix ensures that collapsing happens at the logical text line level while maintaining all existing functionality for incomplete line concatenation and respecting different severities and sources.

Fixes #251701.

title: Fix race condition in tunnel forwarding causing port setting reversions
body:
When configuring multiple ports simultaneously in the tunnel forwarding extension, changing the privacy or protocol settings for one port would cause changes to other ports to revert. This was due to a race condition in the port update logic.

## Root Cause

The issue occurred in `extensions/tunnel-forwarding/src/extension.ts` where `updateActivePortsIfRunning()` was called immediately when a tunnel was disposed during privacy/protocol changes, but before the new tunnel with updated settings was fully created. This created a timing gap where:

1. User changes port settings (e.g., privacy from "private" to "public")
2. VS Code disposes the old tunnel → triggers `updateActivePortsIfRunning()` 
3. CLI receives incomplete port list missing the port being reconfigured
4. VS Code creates new tunnel with updated settings → triggers `updateActivePortsIfRunning()` again
5. CLI processes the incomplete state, causing apparent setting reversions

## Solution

Added a 50ms debounce delay to `updateActivePortsIfRunning()` using a `Delayer` pattern consistent with other VS Code extensions. This ensures that dispose+create operations complete before sending the port list to the CLI process.

**Key changes:**
- Added lightweight `Delayer` utility class for debouncing
- Modified `TunnelProvider` to use debounced updates with `updatePortsDelayer`  
- Split the update logic into `updateActivePortsIfRunning()` (debounced) and `doUpdateActivePortsIfRunning()` (actual implementation)

The fix prevents the race condition by ensuring the CLI only receives complete, consistent port states rather than intermediate incomplete states.

Fixes #253643.

title: Fix: Disabling a tool in a toolset disables the whole toolset in the tool picker
body:
When a user disables a single tool within a toolset in the chat tool picker, the entire toolset becomes disabled the next time the tool picker is opened. This creates a frustrating user experience where users cannot selectively disable individual tools while keeping the toolset enabled.

## Root Cause

The issue was caused by overly restrictive logic in both the tree and legacy implementations of the tool picker. After collecting the user's selections, special handling code for MCP toolsets would override the toolset state, forcing it to be enabled only if ALL tools in the toolset were enabled:

```typescript
// Problematic logic (removed)
for (const item of toolsService.toolSets.get()) {
    if (item.source.type === 'mcp') {
        const toolsInSet = Array.from(item.getTools());
        result.set(item, toolsInSet.every(tool => result.get(tool))); // Forces toolset off if any tool is disabled
    }
}
```

This meant that if a user disabled even one tool in a toolset, the entire toolset would be marked as disabled when the picker results were saved.

## Solution

Removed the override logic that was forcing MCP toolsets to be disabled when any individual tool was disabled. Now:

- **Toolset state** is determined by the user's selection of the toolset/bucket itself
- **Individual tool states** are managed independently and preserved correctly
- **User experience** allows selective enabling/disabling of tools within an enabled toolset

The fix applies to both the new tree-based picker (`showToolsPickerTree`) and the legacy flat-list picker (`showToolsPickerLegacy`).

## Behavior Change

- **Before**: Disabling any tool in a toolset → entire toolset becomes disabled
- **After**: Toolset state and individual tool states are independent → users can disable specific tools while keeping the toolset enabled

Fixes #259920.

title: Fix testing.toggleInlineCoverage action appearing when it shouldn't be available
body:
The `testing.toggleInlineCoverage` action was incorrectly appearing in the editor title when extensions create test runs programmatically without a TestRunProfile, even though the action doesn't function in this scenario.

## Problem

When extensions use the VS Code API to create test runs without a TestRunProfile and add file-level coverage using `addCoverage()`, the toggle inline coverage action would appear in the editor title but clicking it would do nothing. This created a confusing user experience where a visible action had no effect.

## Root Cause

The action's menu condition was based on the `testing.hasCoverageInFile` context key, which is set to `true` whenever any coverage data is reported. However, inline coverage functionality specifically requires detailed per-line coverage information (`CoverageDetails`) that is typically provided through TestRunProfile-based test runs.

## Solution

This PR introduces a new context key `testing.hasInlineCoverageDetails` that specifically tracks when detailed per-line coverage is available for inline display. The key changes are:

1. **New Context Key**: Added `hasInlineCoverageDetails` that is `true` only when `CoverageDetails` are loaded and contain ranges for inline display
2. **Updated Menu Condition**: Changed `testing.toggleInlineCoverage` to use the new context key instead of `hasCoverageInFile`
3. **Preserved Existing Behavior**: Other coverage actions (toolbar toggle, filter) continue using `hasCoverageInFile` as they serve different purposes

## Impact

- ✅ The toggle inline coverage action now only appears when it can actually function
- ✅ Extensions creating test runs without TestRunProfile no longer show non-functional UI
- ✅ Fully backward compatible - existing extensions continue to work unchanged  
- ✅ Other coverage functionality remains unaffected

The fix ensures that the action visibility matches its functionality, providing a cleaner and more predictable user experience.

Fixes #259459.

title: Fix terminal-suggest completions showing up in Python REPLs
body:
Terminal-suggest completions were incorrectly appearing in Python REPLs when they should only be available for supported shells (bash, zsh, fish, pwsh). 

The issue occurred because the `getTerminalShellType` function was accepting 'python' as a valid shell type and returning `TerminalShellType.Python`, even though Python was not included in the `getShellSpecificGlobals` map. This allowed Python REPLs to still receive some completions through path executables.

**Changes:**
- Modified `getTerminalShellType` to return `undefined` for Python shells, causing the completion provider to return early
- Removed `Python` from the `TerminalShellType` enum since it's not supported
- Added comprehensive unit tests to verify Python filtering and ensure other shells continue working
- Improved debug logging to show which shell types are rejected

**Behavior:**
- **Before:** Python REPLs could receive terminal-suggest completions through path executables
- **After:** Python REPLs receive no terminal-suggest completions at all
- **Unchanged:** bash, zsh, fish, pwsh, and gitbash continue to work normally

The fix is surgical and minimal - when a Python REPL is detected, the completion provider now returns early on line 251-254, preventing any completions from being offered.

Fixes #259916.

labels.description: Issue identified to be caused by an extension

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No, this is related to the Go extension

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.102.3 (commit: 488a1f239235055e34e673291fb8d8c810886f81)
- OS Version: Windows 11 10.0.26100

Steps to Reproduce:

### **Assuming the path to your project/workspace is `D:\source\myproject`**

1. Run `dlv debug --headless --listen=:4081 --log` (arbitrary port) on a linux machine or container
2. Configure remote debugging in `launch.json`, using `substiturePath` and map from `${workspaceFolder}`:
```json
{
    "name": "Connect to Docker",
    "type": "go",
    "request": "attach",
    "mode": "remote",
    "port": 4081,
    "host": "127.0.0.1",
    "substitutePath": [
        {
            "from": "${workspaceFolder}",
            "to": "/app"
        }
    ]
}
```
3. Start debugging and put a breakpoint in any file, hover your mouse over it and you will see `could not find file D:\source\myproject\path\to\file.go`

NOTE: using `"remotePath": "/app"` instead of `substitutePath` causes the same issue.

However, when you change `${workspaceFolder}` to the actual path, assuming its `D:\source\myproject` as stated earlier, and use backslashes in the path: `"from": "D:\\source\\myproject"` then remote debugging works. if you use the exact same path (not `${workspaceFolder}`) but with forward slashes instead of backslashes then you can the same issue as before (`"from": "D:/source/myproject"`)

title: Assisted MCP server installation should support custom package sources

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: chat-mcp-management
labels.description: Issues related to browsing and managing MCP Servers in VS Code

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Right now, the npm, Python, NuGet, and Docker MCP server installation flow is hard coded to check the central (public) registries for whether the MCP server exists. This is good for the majority of cases, but it would be great if the custom package sources (such as Azure Artifacts, GitHub Package Registry, or Artifactory) could be used too.
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/blob/518c22efd9664945024985a4c00fe1e44ddac1d3/src/extension/mcp/vscode-node/commands.ts#L202

I propose we use tooling native to the package ecosystem instead of making HTTP requests directly to the registry, if possible. For example, call out to `npm` CLI or `dotnet` CLI instead of making REST calls in proc.

This would also relate to the current working directory that the MCP server is launched from, since package manager CLIs often use cwd to determine config (such as .npmrc or NuGet.config).

Right now, MCP servers have their cwd default to homedir. I think this should probably be the workspace directory (first, in a mutli-root workspace, arbitrarily) instead of homedir. The would be a better default for the MCP server assisted flow since there is no place to specify the cwd -- VS Code mcp.json DOES have a place to configure it but it defaults to homedir as mentioned before.

For NuGet, this would look roughly like:
- Use the workspace dir for cwd instead of a temp dir or homedir.
- Use `dotnet package search <id> --exact-match` to check if the version exists on any configured source
  - this does not return owners (publisher), we would probably need to special case to nuget.org if its in `dotnet nuget list source`
- the rest of the flow is the same (use `dotnet` tooling to install the local tool to check the `server.json` per https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/257679)

A lot of this logic applies to MCP Registry integration too. There is no guarantee a package name in server.json is on the central package registry.

title: Feature Request: Add API to query GitHub Copilot subscription tier
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

The Pylance extension would benefit from understanding a user's GitHub Copilot subscription tier (free, pro, pro+) to optimize resource usage and deliver appropriate user experiences.

Currently, we rely on workarounds such as checking available models to infer subscription status, but these methods are unreliable. We would appreciate an API like vscode.lm.getCopilotSubscriptionInfo() that returns subscription tier information. This would help extensions like Pylance to enable AI-powered features based on user capabilities.

title: Allow extensions to collect extension logs automatically through issue reporter
body: ### Problem Today, when a user wants to file an issue through VS Code, they have to fill out a form. In the form, extensions are able to request specific user actions via the markdown (go to this output, copy paste this, etc). Some users miss this or don't do it and it takes longer to troubleshoot issues with users as we try to gather information after the fact instead of in the moment when they're experiencing the problem. It can also be a lot of actions and multiple steps for something like the C# experience in VS Code where we could need logs from the test explorer, C#DK, and/or C# extension etc. We've also received feedback internally from MS developers that these number of steps is a deterrent from filing issues when dogfooding C#DK. ### Request Since the `Developer: Open Extension Logs Folder` exists, it would be great if VS Code could enable extensions to immediately collect the contents of that folder through the issue reporter. It could go at the bottom as a checkbox that is selected by default and tells user what it is doing like the system info and A/B testing items.
